data.title: WORLD
data.text:
While many Polish troops had fought for France during the early period of the Napoleonic Wars it was not until 1807 after the Treaty of Tilsit that the Grand DuchyÂ of Warsaw was formed by Napoleon I of France. It was a distinctly Polish state formed from Polish lands ceded by the Kingdom of Prussia. The state was nominally under the command of Napoleonâs ally King Frederick Augustus I of Saxony. The Polish people hoped that by aiding Napoleon against their traditional enemies of Russia and Prussia that once again an actual Kingdom of Poland would once again be formedÂ rather than simply being a Duchy. King Frederick never really ruled Poland as his authorityÂ was subordinate to that of Napoleon who essentially ruled the state throughÂ the French ambassador in Warsaw. It was the soldiers and manpower ofÂ the Grand Duchy that Napoleon wasthe most interested in. Between 1807 and the beginningÂ of the ill fated Russian campaign of 1812 the Army went from approximately45,000 men to nearly 200,000 from a country of only 3,000,000 people. What made the Polish troops most effective was the fact that for years they had suffered fromÂ partition and were at the mercy of the Russians to the East, the Prussians to the NorthÂ and the Austrians to the South. They fought for their homeland as much as for theÂ Emperor of the French.

The leader of the Grand Duchyâs army was Minister of War, Joseph Poniatowski.Â He was born in Vienna on May 7, 1763. He was the nephew of King Stanslaw II. He served in the Austrian Army in 1780 and was a representative to the RussianÂ court in 1787. He was appointed Major General in the Polish Army and served in theÂ Polish-Russian war in 1792. In 1806 he was made commander of the Polish forcesÂ fighting alongside the French. In 1807 when the Grand Duchy of Warsaw was formedÂ he was made Commander in Chief of the Polish Army. He introduced universal conscriptionÂ in 1808 which united the Polish people by making them more patriotic.Â In 1809 when Austrian troops invaded Poland he led an army of 12,000 menÂ against 25,000 Austrians at the battle of Raszyn on April 19, 1809. The Polish infantryÂ held against the Austrians later he led harassing cavalry attacks against the AustriansÂ with such success that the Treaty of Schonbrunn was signed which reunited WestÂ Galacia and Krakow with the Duchy. His gallant leadership fired patriotism in theÂ Poles and the ranks of the army swelled.

In 1812 he led over 100,000 of his troops into Russia with the French invasion. His troops fought valiantly at the Battles of Borodino and Smolensk where he was wounded. After the failure of the campaign he covered the rear of the retreating French army. 72,000 of the Polish troops were lost. As the Russian army followed the retreating French and their allies Poniatowski chose to stand with Napoleon and led his troops into Germany to avoid the Russians. In October of 1813 he was given the rank of Marshal of France. The only foreigner to ever receive this honor. At the battle of Leipzig he was wounded and drowned while trying to cross the River Elster.
